awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Trustworthy Cyber-Physical Additive Manufacturing with Untrusted Controllers
awd_abstract_narration:
Additive manufacturing is finding increased application in industry. Safety-critical products, such as medical prostheses and parts for aerospace and automotive industries are being printed by additive manufacturing methods, but there currently are no standard methods for verifying the integrity of the parts that are produced. Trustworthy operation of industrial additive manufacturing depends on secure embedded controllers that monitor and control the underlying physical manufacturing processes. This research will investigate a perfectly air-gapped intrusion detection solution for cyber-physical industrial additive manufacturing infrastructures in which some of the controllers may be infected by malicious code. The research will provide guidelines to: i) tie together resilience solutions in software security, control system design, and signal processing, and ii) incorporate reliable and practical cyber-physical attack detection into real-world manufacturing. Educational and technology transfer activities will address the need to improve the applicability of training methods to ensuring the safety and cyber security of physical control systems. Activities will involve The Society of Women Engineers and a large population of underrepresented and low-income minorities with diverse cultural backgrounds and improve the security of existing, real-world, additive manufacturing systems in industry. 

Next generation cyber-physical additive manufacturing enables advanced product designs and capabilities, but increasingly relies on highly networked industrial control systems that present opportunities for cyber attacks. The predominant approach to defending against these threats relies on host-based intrusion detectors that sit within the same target controllers, and hence are often the first target of the controller attacks. This project will research contact-less and perfectly air-gapped intrusion detection by analyzing physical side-channels to protect against cyber-physical attacks. This solution requires no runtime overhead on real-time controllers, requires minimal change to legacy systems, and reliably identifies intrusions even if the target system is completely compromised. The work will address solutions for: i) air-gapped intrusion detection on cyber-physical systems while maintaining a perfect air gap, ii) a comprehensive understanding of the types of side-channels available for analysis in different industrial systems, and iii) empirical validation of the various perfectly air-gapped intrusion detection tools, both independently and working in tandem.

por.por_cntn:
Next generation cyber-physical additive manufacturing enables core societal functionalities; however, its increasing reliance on highly networked industrial control systems opens doors to threats. The predominant approach to defending against these threats relies on host-based intrusion de- tectors that sit within the same target controllers, and hence, often become the first target of the controller attacks. This project  developed robust contact-less and perfectly air-gapped intrusion detection and security protection against adversarial attacks of different types such as espionage, intellectual property theft, and manufacturing process corruption. Our solutions achieved our security objectives through the analysis of physical side-channels such as optical, accoustic, magnetic, thermal, and physical motion side channels. Our air-gappd security solutions provided no runtime overhead on real-time controllers, requires minimal change to legacy systems, and reliably identifies intrusions even if the target system is completely compromised.

Our project was through collaborative integrated research tasks among PIs from the Rutgers University and Georgia Tech. The first research activity was focused on real-time physical vetting through side-channels. An indicator of an infected controller is a change in a physical process. This inevitably causes a change in sound, movement, or other physical by-products of the process. We developed algorithms to reliably identify unauthorized changes to an industrial process in real time through the analysis of the aforementioned side-channels. Second, we investigated solutions for post-print product integrity checks through advanced imaging. In additive manufacturing, the potential is high for mass produced made-to-order manufacturing. However, this would allow for malicious internal structure changes, while maintaining the external appearance of a product. We leveraged technologies such as Raman spectroscopy and computerized tomography scanning to embed markers into additive manufactured products so that their internal structure may be viewed in post production and vetted for malicious errors. Thirdly, we investigated robust techniques for contact-less controller monitoring via electromagnetic emissions. Even if a host-based intrusion detector is bypassed, the target of an attack still must physically execute malicious code. This causes near-field electromagnetic fluctuations that can give away the intention of the attacker. We utilized emanations from controllers to identify anomalies.

In terms of broader impact, our developed foundational solutions provided guidelines to i) tie together resilience solutions in software security, control system design, and signal processing; and ii) incorporate reliable practical cyber-physical attack detection into real-world manufacturing. As a part of this project, we trained researchers and students on trustworthy manufacturing. Additionally, our team has collected large datasets of the manufacturing processes that are available for download by public. Our outreach activities included educational initiatives such as regular lectures and knowledge dissemination to our industry partners, workshops, and conference talks. Our educational and broader impact activities aimed to break down the barriers between the training and use of physical control system safety and cyber security.
